author: Gabrielle Fonrouge
title: Teacher fired for ‘bullying’ student who didn’t stand during pledge | New York Post
text:
An Illinois teacher was fired for reprimanding a student for not standing during the Pledge of Allegiance, according to a report.
Vince Ziebarth, a drivers-ed teacher at Eisenhower High School, was axed on March 16 for making “inappropriate comments” to 15-year-old Shemar Cooper, the Chicago Tribune reported. 
The boy’s mother, Kelley Porter Turner, said Ziebarth told her son, “If you want to drive with me, you have to stand for the Pledge of Allegiance,” the paper reported.
Cooper said the instructor just “wouldn’t let it go” and his mom reached out to the school and said his son was getting bullied by his teacher and they needed to take care of it.
“If my son didn’t say anything to me, (the teacher) would have continued—that’s bullying,” Porter Turner told The Tribune.
Ziebarth told the paper Cooper and his mom have it wrong.
“I told [Cooper] he can make a choice to sit, but as long as you choose to sit, you will not sit in my (drivers ed) vehicle. I did not tell him what to do,” Zierbarth said.
There are seven other teachers students can sign up with so they can drive with an adult with whom they are comfortable.
“We had an understanding. He was making a choice, and I was making a choice. His name never appeared on my sign-up sheet again, so I thought it was over,” Zierbarth said.
“I thought it was best for everyone. I didn’t want my feelings to seep into my instruction unintentionally.”
“I believe the pledge is a sacred thing,” Ziebarth told WGN. 
This isn’t the first time a teacher has gotten in trouble at the Blue Island high school for reprimanding Cooper for his refusal to stand.
Last August, his Spanish teacher tried to forcibly remove him from his seat when he refused to stand for the pledge and told her “America sucks.”
The teacher was disciplined but not fired.
Students upset about Ziebarth’s dismissal have launched a Change.org petition to get him reinstated. 
It currently has close to 800 signatures, with a goal of 1,000.
